The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HASELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: In the Estate of J. H. CLINTON-BAKER, Deceased.
div.p: I HEREBY give notice that all creditors and other persons having any debt claim or demand against the estate of the late JOHN HUGH CLINTON-BAKER, deceased (who died on the 4th day of March 1905 and whose will was provided on the 6th day of April 1905 by Henry William Clinton-Baker one of the executors therein named) should send in par ticulars of such debt claim or demand to me the solicitor for the said executors on or before the 1st day of September 1905 after which date the executors will proceed to distribute the estate among the persons entitled thereto either as legatees or otherwise having regard only to debts claims and demands on which they shall have had notice on or before the said 1st day of September 1905 and the executors shall not be liable for any debts claims or demands of which they shall not have had notice at that date.
Dated 19th July 1905.
L. CARTON DE WIART, Avocat

div.head: ARMY REFORM.
div.p: What Lord Roberts has to say on the sub ject of Imperial Defence will always be listen ed to with respect by those interested in the services; but we doubt if his lordship's words in the House of Lords las week will be paid any attention to by the public gene rally. At home the Army is looked upon as something quite outside the national life: the public are not interested in its welfare, because they have never been educated up to it, nor been taken into the confidence of the Government in regard to the real problem of national defence. The members of both Houses of Parliament are equally indifferent. With the exception of the efforts made by Mr. Balfour a short time back, no Minister has ever taken the trouble to explain to the public his view of what our military requirements are at home and abroad. The majority of the British public are at this moment in absolute ignorance as to what our participation in a Continental war would in volve from a military point of view.

There has been a good deal of tinkering with the Army and auxiliary forces since the South African war, but you will not get a single intelligent individual to admit that we are any nearer at this moment to a solution of the recruiting difficulty than we were before the war. There is some reason to believe that not more than 50 per cent. of the regular Army at home are fitted to go abroad in the event of a war, and it is calculated that it would take the whole of the Army Reserve to make up the deficiency. Lord Roberts has spoken plainly enough, but his lordship was himself associated with the organisation of the military forces of this country for some time after the South African war But he did nothing. He subjected him-

self entirely to the will of an untried civilian War Minister in Mr. Brodrick. The Army Council have now been some time in office, but although it is perfectly well-known that they are not in agreement with Mr. Arnold Forster and his amateur efforts, they have not the spirit to protest. They are entire ly in his hands. What is the result? We have it on the authority of the most distin guished soldier in the country that "our armed forces, as a body, are as absolutely unfitted and unprepared for war as they were in 1899- 1900." These were Lord Roberts' words in the House of Lords. Are we going on like this for ever, or is there any hope of a statesman being forthcoming with the ability to grapple with the military problem? It is a very serious matter, but we are afraid that nothing short of disaster will ever make the British public realise it, and when war comes we have to remember that failure in one part of the Empire involves trouble, and perhaps very grave and serious trouble, in other areas. A defeat near our frontiers in Afghanistan or Persia might entail, among its unpleasant conse quences, a rising in S.Africa, or the appearance of an alarming number of Mahdis and Mullahs in our African possesions.

The war on two fronts, Bismarck's and Germany's nightmare will be our portion if we fail in the opening stages of any great land struggle of the future, and the British Empire fronts in so many directions that we should be lucky to get off with a struggle or two only. A disastrous naval battle is not the only possible death-blow of the Empire. In a death struggle with any powerful antagonist, wounds, that would otherwise seem light, must tell. What would have been our fate had the Amir Abderrahman's death during the Boer War been followed by a Russian advance into Afghanistan? We are accustomed to bear much of the warlike qualities of the Afghans, but we heard the same of the Hunhuses before the Russo-Japanese War, and these guerillas, who fought for the Russians often enough, have exercised ridiculously little influence on the progress of the campaign, and in any case there is much to be said for the policy of relying on ourselves alone.

div.head: M. DELCASSE ON THE ENTENTE.
div.p: The "Gaulois" prints an account of an inter view with M. Delcassé in which the ex-Minister, asked regarding the exchange of visits between the French and British fleets, is represented as defending the following words the policy that was his during his term of office:-

"A serious and effective policy is not actuated by feelings of antipathy or sympathy but interest. Which is our best customer at the present time, Germany or England? Great Britain. We sell her hundreds of millions worth per annum. What does Germany buy from us? Nothing almost. But she sells us everything she can.

"But supposing we raise the discussion to a somewhat higher plane, is it to be thought that we can fight England if we leave irritating questions open between her and ourselves? For one ship that we build she puts three, four, or five on the stocks. It is better then to bow to cold reason and calculate what British power can avail us in certain eventualities at the cost of some apparent, not real, sacrifices on our part. What such support can do for us is to make it practically impossible for Ger many to declare war on us."
"Then," said the reporter, "all the threats of war since the outset of the Morocco incident did not seem serious to you?"

"Not at all. What would Germany's grow ing fleet do in a case of a war, in which Great Britain would assuredly be with us against Germany? What would happen to her com mercial ports, to her merchant marine? It would be annihilated. That is the meaning of the visit, thought out and planned, of the British squadron to Brest, and the visit sub sequently to be paid by a French squadron to Spithead will complete the demonstration.
Then, becoming more animated, M. Delcassé exclaimed, "Has Morocco ever concerned Ger many? Has Germany ever concerned Morocco? Is it not the natural continuation of our North African Empire?

"Yes, sir, mark this well. The entente cor diale was a step forward towards the detente of differences between Russia and Great Britain, a detente of which the French Foreign Minister was able and will always be able to contrive."

M. Delcassé, moreover, the "Gaulois" con tinues, was not afraid of war. He thought we ought to know how to use the Anglo-German conflict to our advantage. In the eventuality of a conflict with Germany, he told the Council of Ministers at which he resigned, we were in a position to reply to our neighbour's attack.
In conclusion, M. Delcassé, referring to the acceptance of a conference by France, declared that to go to the conference was a mistake, and a very great one.

div.p: The "Liberté" learns from St. Petersburg that the Emperor received Admiral Rodjest vensky's report on the 10th of July. The Admiral ascribes the defeat to the defect in guns, ammunition and ships due to administ rative corruption, and also to mutinous and incompetent crews. A mutiny broke out at Madacascar, and again off Formosa, and finally during the battle, when the crews of the Seniavin and Apraxin refused to fight, and part of the other crews followed their example.
(Reuter.)

The police ordered the Congress of the Zemstvos to break up. On refusal they took the names of the delegates. The Congress resolved that M. Bouliguin's scheme for a National Assembly is, so far as known, totally inadequate, but they decided to participate therin, even if unimproved, with a view to securing further concessions.
(Reuter.)
The Zemstvos Congress has rejected the Bouliguin project for a constitution as being inadequate.
(Havas.)

The mystery of the British steamer Oldha mia, supposed to have been sunk by the Baltic Fleet on the eve of the battle of Tsushima, has been cleared up. A lieutenant and 13 marines, formerly of the Suvaroff, have landed from a boat at Enduma, in the island of Saghalien, and have been taken prisoners. They state that they were ordered to navigate the Oldhamia to Vladivostok, but that she grounded in a fog at Urupp Island and was burnt and abandoned on the 17th June. The boat has been drifiting since then. Some of the crew are still at Urupp Island.
(Reuter.)
The Minnesota, with the Japanese pleni potentiaries on board, has been sighted on the American coast.
(Reuter.)
The Deputy Governor-General of Finland has been wounded by the explosion of a bomb as he was leaving the Senate. The thrower escaped.
(Reuter.)
HOUSE OF COMMONS.-The Aliens Exclusion Bill has been read a third time.
(Reuter.)

King Edward telegraphed to M. Rouvier his personal thanks for the reception given to the British Fleet. M. Rouvier replied that the French Government was glad to give an expression to the mutual sympathy which exists between France and England.
(Havas.)

FIRE IN THE HARBOUR.-A small fire oc curred early this morning on board a house boat moored off Ras el-Tin Palace belonging to Ahmed Bey Soliman. No very serious damage was done.

SUEZ CANAL.-6 vessels passed through the Canal on the 18th ins., 2 of which were British, 2 Dutch, 2 French. The day's receipts were frs. 183,334.90, making the total from the 1st inst. frs. 5,136,045,85.

THE PLAGUE.-Yesterday's bulletin records a fresh case at Alexandria. The patient is a sister of teh girl who was attacked by the disease on the 17th inst. and has since been confined to Chatby hospital. A fatal case is also reported from Port Said.

PONT LIMOUN-MARG RAILWAY.-The Mini ster of Finance has opened a credit of L.E. 6,800 for the improvement of the Zeitoun and Koubbeh Palace stations, on the Pont Limoun- Marg line, and for the construction of barriers on both sides of the permanent way. We are glad to hear that something is at last being done to diminish the number of accidents, often fatal, that constantly occur along this railway.

UNION ARTISTIQUE FRANCAISE.-The drama tic performance given at the San Stefano Casino last night by the above club attracted a large and fashionable audience. The first item on the programme was a "buffonerie judiciaire" in one act, entitled Un Client Sérieux, which caused a good deal of merriment. The "clou" of the evening, however, was L'Envers d'un Riban, a one-act comedy by M. Bonis-Charanele, in which M. Stephanos, as M. Mocassin, especially distinguished himself. The other parts were also in good hands. A very pleasant evening was brought to a close by the interpretation of a short vaudeville, Les Deux Timides, which was cleverly given.

EGYPTIANS IN THE AUTUMN.-Says the "Daily Report":-"So many people imagine Egypt to be a British possession, that the recent warning about the simultaneous registration of companies in Cairo as well as at Somerset House is necessary. Egypt is quite inde pendent of England, and has her own Com pany laws, which are, however, simple and efficient. The recent tendendcy to buy Egyptian shares, especially in the mining section, should expand, and the withdrawal of carry-over facilities will, by shaking out a few stale accounts, render the position of the market more healthy. By October great activity is expected in all Egyptian financial concerns, and Nile Valleys at 1 3/16, Um Rus at par, and Egyptian Mines at 13s. are extremely at tractive as lock-up ventures for the autumn."

BRITISH CHAMBER OF COMMERCE.-We would draw the attention of manufacturers and mer chants to the work of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt, which was formed in 1896 with the sole object of assisting British trade in this country. The services of the Chamber are always at the disposal of any member desiring information on trade matters generally, including the question of appointing suitable agents. As no fee is charged for such advice, it is obviously in the interests of all British traders here to become members, especially when it is remembered that the annual sub scription is merely the nominal one of £1. The latter payment also includes a copy of the monthly Journal issued by the Chamber. Home enquirers can obtain further particulars from our London office, 36, New Broad-Street, which acts as agents to the Chamber.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Referring to the fact that five peerages are borne by the Curzon family, the "St. James's Gazette and Evening Standard" says:-"Per haps the most remarkable family of all is the Barings. They hold four peerages; the Earl doms of Northbrook and Cromer, and the Baronies of Ashburton and Revelstoke. The oldest of these titles is the Barony of Ash burton, which only dates back to 1835, so that practically they have all been won by two generations.
"Al Mokatam" states that Sheikh Amin el Mahdi is expected to succeed the late Sheikh Mohamed Abdou as grand Mufti
Mr. E. B. Gould, I.S.O., H.B.M.'s Consul- General at Alexandrial, and Mrs. Gould were among the passengers who left for England yesterday by the Moss steamer Seti.
Canon and Mrs. Ward are leaving Egypt on Tuesday by the P. & O. steamer Mongolia.
We learn that MR. W. H. B. Evans, who has figured so prominently as one of Oxford University's best cricketers, will come to Egypt in the autumn to occupy a position in the Government.
Amin Bey Ghali, Chief of the Parquet at the Mixed Tribunals, is expected to leave for Europe to-day.

div.head: SUBMERGED SITES.
RECLAMATION FOR BUILDING PURPOSES.
div.p: Ever since the question of the rise of house rents was first raised, some two or three years ago, the population of Alexandria has rapidly and steadily increased. Pari passu there has been an increase in the amount of speculation both in house property and in the waste lands that surround the town. Several companies in the form of banks have been created for the purpose, and the Municipality has acquired very large areas belonging to the Government. Previously the Government was always ready to sell off these areas by sections to indivi duals, but their occupation by the Municipality has prevented their sale, while speculation has so increased the price of land that, in spite of the abundance of building sites and of areas that have not been taken up, but are mono polised by syndicates (of which the Munici pality is involuntarily the chief), rents are steadily rising and the working classes are feeling the pinch.

We have frequently maintained that if the Municipality is to help the public effectively, it can only do so by selling the "terrains libres appartenant à l'Etat" which are at its disposal or by letting the Government continue to sell them as before.

But if, for reasons which we cannot at present discuss, all the land concessions to the Municipality cannot be resumed by the Go vernment, there remain certain areas where some relief for the prevailing pressure and over-crowding may be found. We mentioned yesterday that a project for the utilisation of Anfouchy bay was under consideration, and we are now assured that a company which is being formed will ask the Government for a concession, not of any areas already enclosed, which possess a considerable value thanks to the artificial rise of prices, but of the shallowest parts of the bay where the sea cannot be and never has been utilised.

We hear that the company proposes to fill up and reclaim the shallows in (1) the old port between the Arsenal and Ras el-Tin Palace (2) the whole of ANfouchy Bay for an area one kilometre in length by from 600 to 800 metres in breadth; (3) the east port along a shallow strip of one kilometre in length situated between Kait Bey and the Gouvernorat.

Useless for the present and the future, if left as they are, these areas are thoroughly sheltered and, owing to their level character, should one day give us the best quarters in Alexandria. The old port might be used for Government buildings, Anfouchy Bay for work men's houses, and the East port for small flats, etc., and while the look of the town would be improved, the supply of new quarters would greatly diminish the present overcrowding. At present we hear so much of building at the other end of Ramleh, on the western side of Mex, on the south side of the Mahmoudieh Canal, and by the Mariout lake, that we think it necessary to call the attention of our fello townsmen to the fact that it is perhaps, hardly necessary to go so far afield for build ing sites. Mex and Ramleh will always be popular for climatic or social reasons with the wealthier class of tenants, but a new work men's quarter ought to be as near as possible to the centre of town, pace the eloquent but unconvincing advocates of garden cities.

div.head: ALTERATION OF ROTATIONS.
div.p: The Ministry of Public Works has issued the following notice concerning the rota tions:-

Owing to the continued slow rise of the Nile rotations allowing 6 days' working and 12 days' stoppage will come into force gene rally throughout the Delta from July 24. Rotations in rice districts will be generally five days' working and five days' stoppage.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner Seti sailed yesterday after noon for Liverpool viâ Malta, with passengers, mails, and general cargo, including 4,707 bales cotton.
The Khedivial mail steamship Prince Abbas will leave Alexandria on Wednesday for Praeus, Mitylene, Constantinople, and Smyrna.

div.head: THE CHERIF OF MECCA.
PROBABLE SUCCESSOR.
div.p: In well-informed circles it is stated that Abd el Allah Pasha, a member of the Turkish Legislative Council, will succeed the late Om Rafik Pasha as Cherif of Mecca.

div.head: ACCIDENT TO BRITISH STEAMER.
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.)
div.p: The S.S. City of Manchester, from Liverpool, bound to Calcutta with general cargo, struck a rock in the Canal and is making water. She is now anchored in the Suez roads, where she will discharge part of her cargo into lighters in order to undergo pro visional repairs. Owing to her length she will probably not be able to enter this dry dock.

div.head: STRANDING OF THE S.S. "ANNAM".
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.)
div.p: The Messageries Maritimes steamer Annam, which was reported by Reuter as being aground at Zeila, arrived at Suez last Tuesday afternoon and entered the Canal for Marseilles with about 60 passengers on board.

In the Red Sea, the Annam, owing to the strong currents, was one day drifting consider ably, and towards the evening she grounded at Zeila on a sand bank. At daybreak H.M.S. Perseus went to her assistance and offered to take her passengers on board and convey them to Djibouti, but the latter, being assured by the captain that there was no danger, decided to remain on board with the steamer.

In the meantime a tug with lighters was sent to the scene, and the Annam began discharging cargo, and thus came off in high tide without assistance, amidst the cheers of the passengers and the crew of the man-of-war.
Had the vessel not come off in high tide H.M.S. Perseus was prepared to pull her off.

div.head: OPEN-AIR CONCERT AT KASR-EL-NIL.
div.p: The open-air concert which was held on Wednesday evening at the Kasr-el-Nil bar racks was attended by a large number of people and proved to be the most enjoyable of those which have been held this year. Mr. R. Watson Ramsay, bandmaster of the 2nd Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, had arranged an excel lent programme, and each performer did his utmost to please the audience and without exception succeeded in doing so. The first item was Langley's overture "Evening Breeze," excellently played by the band of the Innis killings, and this was followed by the comic song "The Kerbstone Millionaire," sung by Sapper Noy, R.E., with such humour that he was called upon to repeat it. Captain Tucker then sang "Father O'Fiynn" and, as an encore, "My dear Old Dutch," and in both these songs the fulness and power of his voice were ad mirably shown and his rendering of them was greatly appreciated. Corporal Cooke followed with a horn solo and next came Mr. S.H. Trimen, who sang "Mingle your eyebrows with mine." Mr. Trimen is a great exponent of the art of singing a humorous song, and is invariably met with great applause, which he thoroughly deserves, and needless to say an encore was demanded from him, for which he gave us "Cora" from "The Toreador." Mus. Jackson followed Mr. Trimen with "One of the Upper Ten," which he sang in excellent style, and then came a display of torch-swinging by a troupe of five. This was exceedingly well done, and it was a very pretty sight to see the ten torches being swung in all sorts of posi tions and with perfect precision.

The second half of the programme was open ed by the Inniskilling band, which played "In Coonland," and Captain James, who has a very good baritone voice, followed with "Widdicombe Fair" and "I attempt from love sickness to fly." Next came Dr. Brabant, who played a Cavatina on the violin admir ably, and after this treated us to the inter mezzo from "Cavalleria Rusticana," in which he showed the great command he has over his instrument and the beautiful tone he is able to produce from it. Major Donegan, R.A.M.C., followed and delighted the audience with his original efforts. Whenever Major Donegan appears on the platform one can be sure of hearing something previously unheard, and his songs, the words of which are, we understand, always of his own composition, are invariably thoroughly clever and humorous. He sang about the new Army Regulations, the establishment of peace between Japan and Russia, and "a prety little nursemaid in Ghezireh," for whom he had acquired such great affection that matrimony ensued, and the audience were very loth to let him leave the stage. Downe's mandoline band, consisting of five mandolines and one banjo, played "Sleeping Flowers" very well, and Sapper Porter protested in very comic verse that "He was not so drunk as all that," after which Mr. S. H. Trimen appeared in nautical costume and sang "The Captain said 'I'll stick to the Ship,' " and a most en joyable evening was then brought to a con clusion by the playing of "God Save the King."
We anticipate spending many more such evenings, as it is intended to hold these con certs every alternate Wednesday throughout the summer. The next concert will take place on August 2.

div.head: THE HOLY LAND.
INTERESTING RESEARCHES.
div.p: The scientific exploration of the antiquities of Palestine is advancing successfully. At the annual meeting of the Palestine Exploration Fund, held on Friday last, with the Arch bishop of Canterbury in the chair, Major- General Sir Charles Wilson gave an interesting account of the progress of the work recently conducted at Gezer, and the results of the further excavations of the castle.

Mr. R.A.S.Macalister found there what is apparently the site of an early palace and many minor objects of more than ordinary interest. The palace has been found to con tain a large pillared hall, which it is believed is of a similar kind to that famous as the scene of Samson's last great exploit at Gaza, and Mr. Macalister from the architectural details of the building at Gezer, has been able to fur nish a very plausible explanation of the man ner in which Samson's feat was carried out. Another building appears to have had a reli gious object; below it were found the remains of the foundation sacrifices, and among the débris were several interesting objects, in cluding a figure of the Goddess of Fertility and a specimen of the rare marriage-scarab of Amen-hotep. In addition to numerous lesser Egyptian objects, a great variety of seals and seal impressions were unearthed, some of them being of very interesting types.

The principal discovery, in the opinion of those interested in Palestine exploration, was a cuneiform tablet. Experts place the date of it as 547 B.C., which is two years later than that found on the same site previously.

The German Oriental Society is about to make a thorough examination of all the syna gogues in Galilee. It is now at work on one at Tell Hum. At Tell mUcesellim, Dr. Schumacher is reported to have found at a depth of more than 30 feet below the surface a series of vaulted tombs which date from about 2000 B.C. The graves contained pottery and Egyptian scarabs in a fine state of preservation.

Dr. Sellid has closed his excavations at Taanach, and intends to publish a full account of the discoveries resulting. Among other relics, he found the skeleton of a Canaanite lady surrounded by the skeletons of five children from about four to 15 years of age. A bronze knife among the remains seems to point to a tragedy, which must have ocurred shortly before everything was covered up, for the orna ments of the lady, the large jars for holding provisions, and a little bronze figure of Astarte were found untouched. There were also several valuable jewels. The most interesting letter unearthed reads as follows:-"To Istarwasur Amanhasir, may Adad preserve thee! Send thy brothers with their carts, and send a horse, thy tribute, and presents, and all prisoners who are with thee to Megiddo on the day of the reception."

div.head: SIZAL CULTIVATION IN EGYPT.
div.p: A question of some interest to Dundee is the development of sizal in Egypt, and its use as a substitute for jute. The jute trade has not been over-prosperous, and some curiosity is expressed in Egypt that the leading Dundee merchants have not devoted much attention to the rival of jute. The railway department in Egypt has been growing sizal on the waste ground adjoining the railways, and although very little levelling or preparation of the soil has been done, large profits have resulted. In some areas a net profit of £35 per acre has been obtained, and the excellence of sizal fibre for ropes, cordage, and other rough descrip tions seems generally admitted. Germany and Turkey are the chief customers for the raw material, and the merchants engaged in the trade are reported to be doing extremely well.
("Daily Report")

Conformément aux propositions de la Délé gation et sur rapport du Président, la Com mission décide l'ouverture des crédits, vire ments et imputations suivants:

1) Crédit de L.E. 140 environ pour la location provisoire d'une machine d'irrigation au jardin Nouzha, à prélever sur le budget extraordinaire, ainsi qu'une dépense à concur rence de L.E. 300, même prélèvement, pour la réparation de l'ancienne machine de ce jardin.

2) Allocation d'une somme de L.E. 50, à la Société Internationale pour la répression de la traite des blanches, par un prélèvement de L.E. 25 sur le budget ordinaire, à ajouter au solde disponible du crédit des allocations.

3) Crédit de L.E. 563 pour le prolongement de 20 mètres du Collecteur-Est, ainsi que pour la construction d'une galerie de raccordement des égouts de la rue Rosette et de la rue d'Aboukir à leur jonction au Collecteur-Est, dépense à prélever sur le solde disponible du fonds de l'emprunt. Plus une dépense de L.E. 50, même prélève ment, pour la déviation de la route de la pro menade pendant les dits travaux.
4) Crédit de L.E. 100 pour la réparation des kiosques du Service des Recettes, à prél[?]ver sur le budget extraordinaire.

5) Crédit de L.E. 550 pour l'achat d'une échelle de sauvetage pour le Service des Pom pier, du même modèle que celle achetée récem ment au Caire, à prélever sur le budget extra ordinaire. Le système étant breveté il ne sera pas fait d'adjudication pour cette commande.

6) Renouvellement du crédit de L.E. 93, ouvert par la Commission la 17 Octobre 1904 pour la fourniture de 4 roues en cautchouc, destinée à la pompe automobile, à prélever sur le reliquat du budget extraordinaire.

7) Crédit de L.E. 50 pour l'achat de mo bilier pour le Musée 1a prélever sur le budget ordinaire et de L.E. 300, pour fouilles à Chatby, à prélever sur le budget extraordinaire, crédits demandés par M. le Dr. Schiess Bey, Président du Comité du Musée.
8) Virement de crédit de L.E. 800, pour l'équarissage de vieilles pierres du Service de la Voirie, à prélever sur le crédit affecté à l'entretien des quais du Canal Mahmoudieh.
9) Majoration des crédits suivants, par voie d'imputations, à concurrence de L.E. 740, à prélever sur la réserve du budget or dinaire:

row.cell: Service de Recettes: frais d'impression et fournitures de bureau
Voirie, Uniformes et fournitures de bureau
Frais divers d'impression et de bureaux

div.p: Sur la proposition de la Délégation, la Com mission autorise également d'imprunter, d'ici à la fin de l'année, les dépénses d'expropriation sur le crédit affecté à ce sujet sur le fonde de l'em prunt, le crédit budgétaire étant épuisé.

Elle décide en outre de porter à L.E. 80, la crédit nécessaire pour l'agrandissement et l'aménagement du Service Sanitaire (bureau des établissements insalubres) et la construction d'une chambre pour le Service des Recettes.

M. Cumbo, appuyé par M. le Dr. Schiess Bey, proteste contre les plantations faites la long de la promenade de Ramleh de toute petite ar bustes et, en tous cas, sur l'époque pendant laquelle ces arbustes ont été mis en place.
La Commission renvoie ces observations au Service des Plantations et attire son attention à cet égard.

La Commission approuve divers excédents et emprisez dont l'évaluation a été arrêtée par le Conseil d'estimation dans sa séance du 26 juin 1905, avec de légères rectifications sug gérées par la Délégation.

Dans les emprises figure une dépense de L.E. 1,159 environ pour l'achat d'un terrain au Gouvernement de 1,932 m.c. environ, en vue des échanges à faire avec le Wakf Abou Siri pour l'élargissment à 30 mètres de la route de Ras el Tin et la cession à la Ville de la place ou se trouve située la Nécropole d'Anfouchy.
La séance est levée à 5 h. 1/2 p.m.

2o Nomination de deux membres suppléants provisoires à la Délégation.

div.head: Le Baie d'Anfouchy
div.p: Devant l'accaparement des terrains à bâtir et la cherte croissante des loyers, nous sommes heureux d'informer nos lecteurs qu'un parti culier, M.Z., va proposer au gouvernement un travail qui augmenterait d'un million de mètres carrés environ la surface des terrains à bâtir [?] Alexandrie. Il s'agirait tout simplement de combler la baie d'Anfouchy et une partie du Port-Est, où l'eau est peu profonde.

div.head: III.-Tribunaux de second degre.
div.p: (a) Tribunaux de première instance jugeant en appel les procés sommaires.
Pendant le cours de l'année, 4 039 appels nouveaux ont été inscrits.
Ce nombre était, en 1903, de 3.352.
Le total des affaires terminées en 1904 s'est élevé à 3.221...
Assistance judiciaire.
Le nombre des demandes d'assistance judi ciaire examinées devant les tribunaux ont été de 196. Sur ce nombre 49 ont été admises et 147 rejetées.
(b)Cour d'appel.
Pendant le cours de l'année 595 appels nou veaux ont été inscrits.
Ce chiffre était, en 1903, de 563.
Le total des affaires terminées, y compris celles arriérées de l'année 1903, s'est élevé à 470...
Assistance judiciaire.
Le nombre des demandes d'assistance judi ciaire examinées devant la Cour a été de 79.
Sur ce nombre, 38 ont été admises et 41 re jetées.

div.head: IV.-Significations judiciaires.
div.p: (Faites par les bureaux d'huissiers).
Les huissiers et leurs délégués ont signifié 707.851 actes dont 405.911 en matière civile et 301.940 en matière pénale.
Ces chiffres sont inférieurs à ceux de l'année 1903 qui étaient de 764.892 dont 423.821 en matière civile.
(Faites administraticement).

Suivant l'accord intervenu, le 17 mai 1902, entre le Gouvernement du Soudan et le Gou vernement Egytien relativement aux signifi cations judiciaires et l'exécution des jugements en matière pénale, le Gouvernement Egyptien a envoyé à celui du Soudan 138 actes à signifier dont 53 en matière pénale et 85 en matière civile. De ce chiffre de 138 il ne restait sans signification, le 31 décembre 1904, que 2 actes en matière pénale et 8 en matière civile.
Et ce, outre 12 jugements, rendus en matière pénale, exécutés au Soudan. Un seul jugement restait à exécuter, le 31 décembre 1904.
Les actes envoyés par le Gouvernement du Soudan au Gouvernement Egyptien sont au nombre de 8.
Ils ont été tous signifiés.
Un Seul jugement en matière civile a été, sur l'ordre du Ministère de la Justice, exécuté par les soins du bureau d'huissier du Tribunal de Tanta.

div.head: Recettes et Depeneses.
div.p: La Comptabilité a réalisé, en 1904, des re cettes s'élevant à L.E. 206.313; mais l'en semble des dépenses des tribunaux indigènes s'est élevé à L.E. 190.363. En 1903 les recettes et les dépenses s'étaient élevées respective ment à L.E. 175.310 et à L.E. 180.383.

div.head: Les avocats
div.p: Il existait jusqu'à la fin de l'année 1903, 163 avocats admis à représenter les parties par devant la Cour d'Appel, dont 2 ont cessé d'être avocats, et 125 devant les tribunaux som maires.
Il existait, en outre, 197 mandataires admis devant les tribunaux de première instance avant la mise en vigueur du décret du 16 sep tembre 1893.
49 demandes d'admission ont été présentées en 1904 à la Cour d'appel:
22 ont été admises devant la Cour d'appel;
24 ont été admises devant les tribunaux sommaires:
3 ont été refusées.
3 poursuites ont été formée directement par devant le Conseil de discipline de la Cour d'appel. De ces poursuites 2 ont abouti à des décisions de radiation et 1 restait à juger au 31 décembre 1904.

Par devant le Conseil de discipline des tri bunaux de première instance, 9 poursuites ont été formées dont 1 a abouti à une décision de radiation, 3 à la suspension, 1 à l'avertissement, 3 à l'acquittement et 1 restait à examiner le 31 décembre.

7 appels ont été soumis à la Cour d'appel (outre 6 qui restaient de l'année 1903). Ces appels ont abouti 1 à la radiation, 6 à la sus pension, 1 à la censure, 2 à l'acquittement, 1 à la radiation de l'appel sur le désistement de l'appelant condamné à la suspension en pre mière instance, et 2 restaient à examiner le 31 décembre.

div.head: Travail interieur du Parquet
div.p: En 1904, les parquets de première instance et leurs délégations sommaires ont soumis à l'examen du Parquet général 129 rapports d'inspection des greffes des tribunaux, de la comptabilité et des bureaux d'huissiers.
Ils ont également présenté 665 rapports d'inspection de police et de prisons.
Ils ont poursuivi par devant le Conseil de discipline 25 commis-greffiers et huissiers.
Ces 25 poursuites ont abouti à 18 condamna tions diverses et à 5 acquittements. Au 31 décembre 1904, il restait 2 affaires sous examen.
Les parquets de première instance ont con trôlé d'office 24.740 affaires sommaires et 2.203 sur plaintes des administrations ou des particuliers.
Le Parquet Général a contrôlé 2.903 affaires dont 476 sur plaintes.
Le nombre d'instructions générales qui ont ont [original typo] été "adressées aux parquets de première instance, en l'année 1904, s'élève à 86, dont 32 adressées directement par le Parquet gé néral.

En 1904, le nombre des requêtes atteignait le chiffre de 104.008 et celui des correspondan ces judiciaires et administratives s'élevait à 1.459.565 dont 729.447 expédiées et 730.118 reçues, contre un total de 1.589.339 en 1903.
Le nombre des correspondances reçues et expédiées par les tribunaux et les greffes s'élève respectivement à 39.765 et 378.191.

div.head: Les Meglis Hasbi
div.p: En 1904, 11 appels ont été interjetés contre des décisions du Méghis Hasbi, 3 appels res taient en 1903, 6 de ces décisions ont été con firmées, 3 annulées, 2 rayées et 3 appels restaient à examiner, le 31 décembre 1904.

Par contre, les Cotton Mills réactionnent de 5/6 à 5/3, les Markets de 23/3 à 23 et l'Alex andria Water de 15 à 14 7/8.
Plusieurs miliers d'Estates ont changé de mains à 7/8.

div.head: Administration des Postes
div.p: L'Administration des Postes met en adjudi cation la fourniture des uniformes nécessaires à son personnel pour les années 1906, 1907 et 1908.

Les personnes qui désirent concourir à cette adjudication peuvent prendre connaissance du cahier des charges tous les jours de 9h. à midi, les Dimanches exceptés, au bureau du Secré tariat de la Direction Générale des Postes à Alexandrie et au bureau du Secrétariat de la Direction Locale des Postes au Caire.

Les offres devront êtres faites sur le tableau annexé au cahier des charges et être accom pagnées d'une feuille de papier timbré de P.T. 3. Elles devront être insérées sous double enveloppe, celle extérieure à l'adresse de S.E. le Directeur Général des Postes à Alexandrie et celle intérieure portant la mention "Offre pour la fourniture des uniformes."
Les offres devront parvenir à la Direction Générale des Postes au plus tard le 16 Octobre prochain à 10h. a.m.
L'Administration se réserve le droit d'ac cepter l'offre qui lui semblera la plus avantageuse et même de ne pas donner suite à l'adjudication.
Alexandrie, le 20 juillet 1905.

div.head: Administration des Chemins de fer et des Telegraphes
AVIS
div.p: Le Conseil d'Administration a l'honneur d'informer le Public qu'une adjudication par "Kaïmet Mounaksa" aura lieu au Bureau de Mr. l'Inspecteur des Magasins des Chemins de fer à Gabbary, le 31 Juillet 1905 de 10h. a.m. à midi, pour l'entreprise de transport par charettes des matériaux entre les divers services et chantiers de l'Administration à Alexandrie.
Le Cahier des Charges contenant les condi tions de cette enterprise est déposé au service des Magasins au Caire, (Boulak) et à Alexan drie (Gabbary) où les intéressés peuvent en prendre connaissance.

div.head: SELF-EXILED.
THE GERMAN IN OTHER LANDS.
div.p: The success of German diplomacy in Morocco has turned attention anew to the policy of adventure and aggression which is supposed to underlie the activity of German statesmen in the foreign field. Englishmen especially are inclined to credit the German people with a deliberate design to extend the territorial dominion of their empire. While this may be true of the German Government, and the men who are promoting the Pan-Germanic move ment, it cannot be said of the average German or of those whom one meets outside their own country and in the backwoods of the world. Whatever has been achieved in colonial ex pansion by Germany has been gained by the bold and skilful manipulation of events by its official class and not by the initiative or assistance of private individuals. In this respect one finds a wide difference between the Englishman and the German as a colonist. When new territory is added to the British Empire it is at once occupied by British subjects ready to prospect and develop its resources, and glad to retain their nationality. Not infrequently they have invaded the region first and remained unsatisfied until they have brought about a political tie with the old country and run up the British flag above their heads.

The emigrant German, on the other hand, is never anxious to bring himself into close relation with his Government. Unlike the British settler, he does not, as a rule, proceed to his own colonies. The stream of German immigration turns towards countries where political and personal freedom exists to a greater extent than in the Fatherland. There are millions of Germans in the United States who are Americans in everything but name, and even the names are also undergoing a rapid process of transformation. Outside of the Union, the largest community is domiciled in South America. There are hundreds of thousands in Southern Brazil, where they have built up a splendid commerce; but it is a sig nificant fact that only a few hundreds have retained their citizenship. In every foreign State and colony in the tropics, they are to be found in considerable numbers.

If we turn to the German colonies, we find a striking contrast to this state of things. The white people in these countries form a mere handful of the total population, and of the whites about two-thirds only are Germans. In the whole of the great colonies in Africa they amount to but a few thousands, while the South Sea protectorates can only account for several hundreds.
Whi is this?

The explanation lies in the character of German colonial administration. The colonies are regarded as economic estates, and are managed on bureaucratic lines. They are part of the iron-bound official system which, what ever its merits, does not attract the free spirit of enterprise that conqueres the most unto ward conditions and fosters commerce and trade. Although Germans have been offered inducements to settle in their over-sea pos sessions, they have not responded with the eagerness which one would expect from a people reputed to be anxious to found a great colonial empire, neither have capitalists shown any disposition to invest money in these undeveloped estates. They have not achieved the success which has attended Bri tish colonies in the same position. Almost all of them are dependent on the home govern ment for financial support; some are heavy charges on the Imperial exchequer, requiring large subsidies to enable them to balance their budgets. Their existence is due to the resolute policy of German statesmen to increase the power and prestige of Germany throughout the world; their failure results from the reluctance of the individual German to migrate to them in any great numbers.

It is not that the German makes an in different colonist. Like the Englishman and Scotsman, he is a natural pioneer and settler, and, like them, takes root in a new country and identifies himself with his environment. The traveller meets them in every land and in the most out-of-the-way corners. The majority are engaged in mercantile and banking busi nesses, many are produce merchants, while a few devote themeselves to agriculture. There is also a considerable number who are expert in employments requiring scientific knowledge.

It is in technical ability and achievement that the German bests the Englishman abroad as well as at home. A single illustration of this may be given. A German chemist went through the forests of a tropical country, examining and testing the substances he came across. He revisited Germany, and after some months returned, and a workshop was set up in the bush. Operations were conducted with the greatest secrecy, and they appeared to be successful, for assistant after assistant was imported from Germany, the works ex tended, and today there is a large annual exportation of commercial stuffs extracted from the products of the woods.

As linguists, also, they are far ahead of Englishmen. The principal English merchant in a French-speaking country informed the writer that he had given up sending fro clerks from England, because they could not, or would not, learn French. He had been compelled to employ Germans, who quickly made themselves indispensable, and when he retired it would be a German that would succeed him.

There are few better settlers than these quiet, plodding, domesticated Germans. They form a steadying factor in the communities in which they dwell, abstaining from med dling in local politics-save in British colo nies, where their assistance in public work is welcomed-and very frequently marrying English women. When this happens they become more detached from home influences, and although they may continue to read German newspapers and take an interest in German affairs, their children grow up British citizens, often without knowledge of their father's tongue; and when they retire it is not the Fatherland that claims them. If there is one point of difference between them and the British, it is that, as a rule, they do not understand the character of native peo ples so well, and do not come into as inti mate and sympathetic relations with them. There are, nevertheless, exceptions to this generalisation. The German Moravian mission aries have a peculiar knack of successfully training the darker races in the arts and graces of civilisation.

The writer has met and associated with Germans of all classes in many countries, but he has never found one who expressed sym pathy with the dreams of Colonial dominion cherished by official Germany. He has come in touch with a natural desire to promote German interests, and occasionally a thrill of pride in German attainment, but along with these has invariably gone a devout hope that the Kaiser's long arm may not reach out and disturb the tranquil tenour of their way. Under ordinary circumstances they do not wish protection from their Government. IT was openly deprecated by the German residents in Venezuela during the memorable crisis: it is always resented whenever there is a tendency to force it upon them. Such an attitude can scarcely be understood in England, but it is a perfectly explicable one. They have gone to the foreign country in order to make a living out of it, accepting the risk the act may involve; they are under the authority of its Government, and probably have been granted concessions by it. It has the power to hamper their movements and reduce their profits in a score of indirect ways, and even to ruin them by means that cannot be made the basis of a diplomatic representation. It is their interest, therefore, to preserve the best of relations with the officials and the people, and they object to the paternal solicitude of their officious Government, except in extreme cases of injustice and peril. The official representa tive of the Emperor is never slow to make capital out of the most trivial incident, but the ordinary residents seldom benefit by his interference. Still less do they desire to see the German flag unfold above them. They may, of course-often do-maintain a strong regard for the home country, but they prefer to show their patriotism by independently promoting its trade rather than by contri buting to the extension of its colonial pos sessions.
W. P. LIVINGSTONE.

div.head: GOVERNMENT AND VOLUNTEERS
div.p: Discussing Mr. Arnold-Forster's Volunteer policy, the "Spectator" says:-We want efficiency quite as much as does Mr. Arnold- Forster. But the Government plan will not secure fighting efficiency, and is not even meant to secure it. It is simply a "reducing powder" intended to get rid of that redundancy in the Volunteers which the Government find so offensive. A good practical way of realising how absurd is the Government's standard of efficiency is to think out what would have happened if it had been applied by President Kruger to the Boer Army. The Boers, it is generally admitted, were pretty efficient fighters; but if all the boys under nineteen and men over forty-five had been rejected, and further, ifall those who suffered from bad teeth or constitutional ailments had also been "cast," we should have found it a very much easier job to overcome them than we did.

No doubt it is not worht while for the Government to take men into a professional army, whose members may have to serve in the tropics for many years together, and who can qualify for pensions, unless they can pass something like a life insurance test. In the case of the Volunteers, however, the thing is ridiculous.

As to the age test, we do not hesitate to say that the men over forty-five who remain in Volunteer regiments are among not only the best shots, but the best men in their corps. Except for the shooting test, which is one so severe that if applied to the Regulars it would probably reduce them to one-third of their present numbers, we do not hesitat to say that the standard sought to be set up is quite impracticable.

div.head: AMERICAN COTTON.
PROPOSED FORMATION OF A PRODUCERS' TRUST.
div.p: The contemplated adoption of the "trust" idea by American cotton-growers (says a special correspondent of "Commercial Intelligence") is a matter of interest to British manufacturers, who would be affected as much as anyone by the success of a satisfactory scheme. Several proposals have already been made, none of which may be adopted, but we may take them as indicating the lines of any ultimate scheme. The plan of the New York Cotton Exchange for the establishment of licensed warehouses in the South, where cotton might be held for delivery on sales made in New York is now in abeyance, and is believed to have little prospect of success.

There is, however, a movement in the SOuth for a local warehousing system, in accordance with which cotton belonging to the planters would be held from the market, with a veiw to "destributing delivery on actual sales" over the year, and maintaining the price. Another proposal is for large warehouses at a few central collecting and distributing points to which the cotton would be sent from a wide tributary territory; but in this case the obje ction is raised that the planters and farmers would not send their cotton away to a distance with out first actually selling it, and the benefit contemplated would not accrue to them. The plan of many independent local warehouses is open to objection on the ground that general concerted action is necessary to success, and that could not be secured without a central organisation covering the whole field.

The latest plan is that recently proposed before the Texas Bankers' Association by an American judge. He suggests a system of warehouses, one at each town, marketing 1,00 bales or more, and would have them owned and managed by a single corporation "organis ed and controlled by the farmers, merchants and bankers of the cotton belt." Among the advantages claimed for this plan are these: That it would afford a place of storage which would save much loss from "country damage," that it would stop the rush of cotton to market in the fall months, offer to spinners the needed grades and quantities and "prevent specula tion," and that it would reduce insurance rates and provide available warehouse receipts, uniform in terms and backed by a warehousing company strong enough to guarantee them. It is also claimed that it would increase the deposits of local banks from the higher prices received by the planters, afford the best collateral for farmers' loans, diminish the rate of interest while increasing the bankers' profits, and encourage cotton mills in the vicinity of the warehouses.

The South is bent on having a more business like system for marketing the cotton crop. Hitherto it has been largely exploited through distant centres engaged in exporting as well as distributing to domestic manufacturers, like New Orleans, Savannah and New York, to the encouragement of wide fluctuations in price and consequent speculation, and the question is whether it is desirable for all the interests concerned that demand and supply should be brought into closer and steadier relation throughout the year, and that the price should be maintained nearer to a stable level.

div.head: TORTURE IN CHINA
div.p: The Italian Consul at Hong Kong has taken an honorable lead in pressing upon Chinese statesmen the abolition of judicial torture. During a residence of 20 years in China, he had studied the question in all its aspects, and some time since translated into Chinese a thesis by the eminent Italian jurist, Beccaria, on "Crimes and Punishments." When the Duke of Abruzzi was in Hong Kong last December he was induced to assist in organising a society having for its object the abolition of torture, and since then many publications have been scattered broadcast among educated Chinese, and espe cially among the Mandarin class. The first fruits of this movement have been seen in the recent abolition of the most ferocious of all Chinese death penalties, the ling-cib, which involved cutting to pieces of the body of the condemend.

div.head: RUSSIAN NAVAL MUTINEERS.
TURKISH PRECAUTIONS CONTINUING.
div.p: Constantinople, July 12.-The feeling of uneasiness caused here by the Potemkin inci dent has not yet entirely disappeared. In fact, the matter still forms a subject of discussion, and fears are even expressed that other Russian warships may follow the example of the Potemkin. The work of replacing the old ordnance of the Kavak forts by twelve new Krupp guns, of laying submarine mines, and installing the electric light is proceeding apace. The mounting of the new weapons in expected to take a considerable time, as many of the emplacements must be altered or reconstructed. The utmost vigilance is being observed by the Turkish authorities, both on land and sea, and in the vicinity of the Rumili Kavak forts sentries are posted every fifty yards, and subject to passers by to a close scrutiny. A Turkish torpedo boat and the despatch boat Izzedin were stationed in Buyukliman Bay yesterday with steam up.
Five hundred men from the Chataldua for tifications have been sent to Kavak to reinforce the garrison.

div.head: CHINESE REFORMERS IN AUSTRALIA.
div.p: Japanese influence is becoming strongly marked among the better class of Chinese resi dents in Australia, and they are beginning to evince a spirit which is regarded by many as a reflex of a newly-awakened feeling in the Celestial Empire. While remaining faithful to their ancient religious traditions, they are evincing a disposition to carry the work of social reform among the lower class of their fellow-countrymen in the Commonwealth, their principal desire being to assist in elevating Chinese character in the estimation of the outside world. In Sydney a start has been made by the Chinese reformers by the esta blishment of an anti-opium crusade. They assert that in proportion to the population there is more opium-smoking in Australia than in China, and they ask for the imposition of Federal legislation on the basis of the Opium Prohibition Act now in force in New Zealand. At a meeting of the Chinese Empire Reform League in Sydney, it was resolved to co-operate with a similar body in Melbourne, a petition, embodying the views of the two organisations, being drafted by a Chinese member of the Victorian bar for presentation to the Prime Minister. The New Zealand law has been found extremely efficient in achieving the purpose for which it was intended. Under its provisions, it is unlawful to import opium in any form for smoking, or to manufacture it for a like purpose. IT is also an offence to smoke the drug, or to permit or abet smoking by others. The penalty for importing opium is £500.

At the Sydney meeting, the Chairman, Mr. L. Yee Hing, President of the Chinese Empire Reform League, stated that a similar Act had stamped out opium smoking in Formosa, and a like result had been achieved in Hawaii, until the American Government had permitted the importation of the drug at a duty of 10 dollars per lb. He explained that statistics secured by him showed what a large amount of opium was imported into the Commonwealth, irrespective of that smuggled. In 1902, the quantity of opium imported into New South Wales was 27,496 lb.; but in 1903 it sank to 1,830 lb. Yet the supply appeared in no way diminished, showing that a large quantity entered the State without paying duty. It is estimated, that the average annual consumption by the Chinese population of New South Wales ex ceeds three pounds per head. According to the Chinese reformers, the annual imports of opium into their native country average about 4,000,000 lb., value £5,000,000 while the Commonwealth imports in 1903 came to 42,439 lb., valued at £59,138, showing that there must be some mistake in the New South Wales returns of 1,830 lb.

As indicating the real character of the new movement, it may be mentioned that among those present at the Sydney meeting were all the prominent merchants interested in the opium traffic, the chairman being the head member of a firm controlling about one= third of the trade in the State. Those pre sent were unanimous in declaring that, as merchants and as dealers, they had more to gain from the abolition of the traffic than by its continuance. But the League is not content with holding meetings of its members alone. It has boldly invaded the Chinese quarters of Sydney and its suburbs, where, instead of ecnountering the anticipated opposition from the low-class Celestials, its work has been hailed with expressions of ap proval, save on the part of the keepers of opium-smoking dens. There is every pros pect of the desired legislation being secured during the approaching Federal Session, unless political difficulties block the way. Throughout the Commonwealth the new movement is being strongly supported by the Chinese of all classes, and full reports of everything taking place are rebularly forwarded to the heads of teh reform party in China.

Apart from the anti-opium movemnet, there are indications of a general Chinese awakening throughout Australia. When it was reported that Germany was contemplating the acquisition of more Chinese territory, the Chinese Empire Reform League immediately cabled to the Chinese Government at Peking as follows:-"Do not allow Gemrany to take any more land; resist the aggression with all your might." There is a settled impression among the Chinese in Australia that the death of the Dowager Empress will be followed by stupen dous changes, in which the Reform party will play a conspicuous part. "What has proved possible in Japan," they say, "is also possible in China, if the right man is at the head of affairs." They believe in an alliance with Japan, and in the friendship of Great Britain. Letters received in Australia by Chinese re formers from their fellow-workers in the Chi nese Empire Reform League are being disseminated among all classes of Chinese people. It is as if the long-slumbering giant were beginning to open his eyes and discover the real strength which may make him, like Japan, a powerful factor in the future history of the East.

div.head: THE MANOEUVRING OF TURBINE STEAMERS
div.p: While it has been admitted, practically on all hands, that the steam turbine has considerable advantages over the reciprocating engine for ship propulsion, and that it is almost certain to be very widely adopted for high-speed vessels, there continues to linger some doubt as to facility in stopping and starting, reversing, and generally of manoeuvring turbine-driven stea mers into piers and confined harbours. This doubt should be largely dissipated by the results of the official trials of the Dieppe, built for the London, Brighton, and South Coast Railway, and the Western Railway of France, fro service between Newhaven and Dieppe. The trials which were carried out between the two ports named were interesting more for the novel requirements in respect of stopping and manoeuvring than for their speed; but in this latter respect the performance of the steamer was certainly remarkable, in view particularly of the fact that the length of hull was limited, owing to the torturous nature of the channel within Dieppe harbour. This required that the length should not exceed 281 ft. on the load line. Fortunately a scheme has now been approaved which, when carried out, will straighten the crooked paths. In the meantime the dimensions of the Dieppe had to be as follows: -Lenght over all, 282 ft.; length on the water-line, 280 ft. 6 in.; breadth, 34 ft. 8 in., depth, 14 ft. 6 in. On trial the mean draught was 9 ft. 3 in., and the displacement 1,360 tons. The vessel was required to make the double passage within such time as necessitated a speed of 21.19 knots, and the return voyage, on the following day, at 21.764 knots, giving a mean speed for the double run-nearly 130 sea miles- of 21.523 knots. When we come to describe this vessel fully, we shall give the details of engine performance, &c. In the meantime, it may be said that the three shafts, each fitted with single screws, and operated-the centre shaft by a high pressure turbine, and the two side shafts by low-pres sure turbines-run at a mean spead of about 640 revolutions per minute. As we have already indicated, however, the interesting features were the rapidity with which full speed could be realised, and the time taken to reverse. Moving away from the quay, only the low pressure wing-shafts and pro pellers were in use, as this greatly facilitated manoeuvring. When the vessel had got into the centre of the harbour, and the order was given, "Full speed ahead," barely 2 1/2 minutes elapsed before the high-pressure turbine was running at a speed of over 600 revolutions per minute. From the time that the vessel left Dieppe Quay until she was passing the light ship at the entrance to the harbour only four minutes elapsed, notwithstanding the torturous nature of this harbour; this of itself is a very satisfactory performance in respect of ma neouvring. Before the vessel had entered Dieppe, the contract required that when run ning at a speed of 12 knots she was to stop within 100 metres. Two boats had been moor ed to mark this distance, and for two miles in advance of the first boat the Dieppe's turbines ran at the rate of revolution which previous performance on the measured mile had deter mined as necessary to give a speed of 12 knots; within six seconds of the order, "Full speed astern," the turbines were running astern, and in 41 seconds the ship herself was moving astern; the distance traversed from the time the order was given to reverse until the ship began to go astern being 100 yards; several yards less than the requirements of the contract. Thus, as regards speed and ma neoeuvring, every condition of the contract was fully satisfied.-"Engineering."

div.head: A MISTRESS MARINER.
div.p: America is still to the fore. Miss Jane Morgan, a young society lady of Philadelphia, has secured a certificate of master mariner, and in fulfulment of a long cherished ambition, she sailed last week to Norway in charge of her father's yacht Waturas. She undertakes the duties of navigation and seamanship in every detail, and hopes to encounter a gale in cross ing the Atlantic, to give her a chance of proving her ability as a sailor. The "Tele graph" says that from Norway, the Waturas proceeds to the Isle of Wight

div.head: POSTAL NOTICE.
div.p: The Post Office Administration offers for sale on behalf of the Postal Mutual Help Society 300,000-three hundred thousand- Egyptian and Foreign obliterated stamps which have been detached from undelivered cor respondence and parcel, despatch notes destroy ed at the expiration of the regulation periods
Tenders may be made for the whole lot, or for a portion thereof, but in the latter case the prices offered per 1,000 stamps of each value should be mentioned.
Intending purchesors should understand that the stamps will be delivered at Alex andria to buyers in their present states, packing and postabe being at buyer's cost. Terms cash on delivery of stamps.

Tenders should be addressed to the General Post Office (Postal Mutual Help Society), Alexandria, and will be received up to the 31st August 1905 inclusive and should be enclosed in double envelopes, the inner one bearing the words "Tender for purchase of old stamps."
The Postmaster General reserves the right of accepting or refusing any tender and declines responsibility for stamps that may be torn or over-obliterated.

Persons wishing to tender will on application to the Seceretary's Office, General Post Office, Alexandria, be shown the detailed statement giving the quantity of stamps of each different value offered for sale.
GENERAL POST OFFICE.
Alexandria, the 18th July 1905.

div.head: AGRICULTURAL BANK OF EGYPT.
New Issue of Shares for Increase of Capital.
div.p: IN PURSUANCE of an Extraordinary Ge- neral Meeting held on the 18th May 1905, the Board of Directors of the Agricultural Bank of Egypt offer 248,000 new shares of the said Bank of Five pounds sterling each. These shares will constitute an increase of the Capital of the Bank, and are issued in conformity with the Statutes at the price of Five Pounds sterling per share, payable on application.
Application should be made:-
in EGYPT to the Head office of the National Bank of Egypt at Cairo and to the Branch at Alexandria.
in LONDON to the London Agency of the National Bank of Egypt, 4 & 5, King William Street, E.C.
The new shares will rank for dividend from the 1st January 1906, that is to say from the beginning of next year.
Every shareholder has the right on applica- tion to an allotment of one new share in respect of every old share held.

All shareholders who wish to exercise their rights must, under pain of forfeiture of those rights, lodge their applications at one of the places named above on or before the 2nd October 1905 depositing their Share Warrants together with the total amount payable, viz: £5 per share.
The President of the Board of Directors, (signed) Elwin Palmer.
Cairo, the 8th July 1905.

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: Société Anonyme
Capital 250,000,000 de francs
Entièrement Versés
Agences d'Égypte:
Alexandrie, Le Caire, Port-Said
Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
